chapter.title: Project Administration
chapter.para: Whenever you enter the Project Summary page of a given project or any of its service you'll see a new section appear in the CodeX Main Menu on the left hand side of the screen. This new section relates to the visited project and points to the Project Summary page and the Project Administration page.
Only project members can access the Project Administration page. All other CodeX users are denied access to this part of a project.

section.title: Project Administration Menu
section.para: In addition to the CodeX Main Menu that was introduced in the description of the Project Summary page, the Project Administration page has its own menu. This menu is not redundant with the page content right below. Except for 1 or 2 items the menu and the page content give access to distinct parts of the administration space. So pay attention to both the Page Admin menu and the Page Admin content. In the following sections the Location label indicates where to find the corresponding administrative function.

section.title: Adding/Removing Users
section.para: User administration in CodeX is easy. To add a new member to a project team one of the project administrator just has to type the login name of the invited member and click on the "Add User" button. If you don't know the login name of the new project member you want to add, open a new browser window on CodeX and use the search box in the CodeX Main Menu to search for the person's real name (first or last name or both) and don't forget to select "People" in the Search pull-down menu. The result list will show you the user real name and login name.

Removing a project member is even easier. Just click on the trash icon () next to the person's name to revoke his/her membership. Revoking membership has absolutely no effect on the history and the data integrity of the project. In other words all bugs, tasks, support requests, ... assigned or submitted by this person will continue to show up as before in the project database. Only the ability of this person to perform project management tasks is affected. Also notice that in order to remove a project administrator from the project member list, another project administrator must first change the "Project Admin" flag of this user to "No" in the User Permission table. In other words, a Project Administrator cannot be removed from the project members as long as she has administrator privilege.

para.note: You have probably noticed that project member's name on the Project Administration page are actually hyperlinks. On this page as well as in many other pages throughout CodeX a click on a login name leads you to the user page where you can know more about the user (including its location, phone/fax number, etc. extracted from the Xerox Directory in real time) and send an e-mail message to this person directly via a Web form.

section.title: User Permissions
section.para: Project Administrators have the ability to grant different permissions to different users. As an example, a project member can be granted full administration rights on the Bug Tracking System and no rights at all on the Documentation Manager of the project.

figure.title: A sample project members permission table

section.para: shows a sample project members permission table. Each column represents a service or a user capability and there is one line per project member. Let's review the column one by one:

listitem.para: Project Admin: A Yes/No flag stating whether a given project member is a project administrator, that is to say a project member with absolutely all rights over the project services, project deliverables and project members. Only Project Admin can access the project members permission page.

CVS Write: Right now this is always set to Yes. All project members have write permission over the CVS
CVS stands for Concurrent Version Control. It is the default source code version control system offered on the CodeX site. CVS is used by hundreds of thousands of software projects allover the world. See http://www.cvshome.org for more information.repository and this cannot be changed from the current version of the Web interface. However we'll see how to deny CVS write permission to project members in the CVS chapter ().

Bug Tracking, Task Manager, Patch Manager, Support Manager : are listed in the upper right corner of the page. A click on a name will direct you to the user page where you can learn more about the CodeX user and send him/her an e-mail. Project members can be viewed via the [View members] pointer.
None: well, you can't do much with this one
Technician Only: tool technicians can be assigned bugs/tasks/patches/support requests and has the ability to update these items from assignment to closure.
Administrator Only: tool administrators have full access to the administration part of the tools. As an example, they can define new tasks categories, new predefined values for bug fields, etc.
Technician & Administrator: the one-man-can-do-it-all on that tool
Forums, Documentation Manager: These 2 services have much less sophisticated permission schema. Only 3 permission levels are available:
None: there is nothing you can do with this service

Moderator: (Forums only): A moderator has the ability to moderate the Web Discussion forum that is to say create/delete discussion forums for the project, delete posted messages and update the Forum status (public/private) as well as the Forum description
Editor: (Doc Mgr only): An editor has the ability to review and validate a document prior to its publication. S/he can also update and delete a document.

important.title: Reminder!
important.para: Don't forget to click on the "Update Developers Permission" button after making any changes in the permission table.

section.title: Project Public Information
section.para: The "Edit Public Info" item of the Project Administration menu allows a project member to update the following project data:

step.para: The Project Home Page: each project hosted on CodeX has its own virtual Web server available on the CodeX site. By default the "Home Page" in the Project Main Menu points to this location (see CHAPTER 16 for more details). If you want the Home Page of your project to point to some other locations on the Xerox Intranet (or even outside of Xerox) replace the default value with your own Web location. Do not confuse your Project Home Page with your Project Summary page. The Project Home Page actually points to real Web Site whereas the Public Summary Page is just an entry point to access software related activities and deliverables.

The Project Description Elements: these are elements provided during the registration process as well as the two-line description that you have provided right after your project registration was confirmed.

The Project Active Services: this is the list of services that you want to enable/disable for your own project. (Un)Checking any of the select boxes will immediately (De)Activate the service. Deactivating a service just means that it disappears from the Project Summary page of your project but all existing data related to this service remains untouched. In other words, re-activating the service will restore the service in the exact same state it was when you first deactivated it.

section.title: Project Categorization
section.para: This is where you can categorize your project. You can define up to 3 values for each of the 7 criteria used in the Software Map. If you cannot find any matching value in the predefined list do not hesitate to contact the CodeX Team.

section.title: Project History
section.para: The Project History provides project members with Audit capabilities. Clicking on this menu item shows a list of all the changes that have taken place in the administration of the project since its creation. The list of changes reports the nature of the change (e.g. Changed Public Info, Changed Permissions, Changed Software Map, ...) , what the value was before it changed (if applicable), who changed it and when.

section.title: Project Data Export
section.para: CodeX is very appealing to many project development teams because it provides full-featured project development and management tools for free. A software project can be managed almost entirely from within CodeX. However at some point the project team needs to report about progress made, what goes well or wrong, how far you are from the end date, derive statistical data, etc.

It is far beyond the scope of CodeX to provide project teams with such reporting tools. There are many specialized tools on the market to generate progress reports and each project team has its favorite one. In order to satisfy this diversity of needs, the CodeX Team has developed a very efficient system that allows the project team to export the project data outside of CodeX for re-use in other tools like Access, Excel, Crystal Report, Word, Open Office, Star Office or any other ad-hoc tools.
CodeX provides you with 2 kinds of Data Export:

listitem.para: Text File Export: this is a simple text extract of your project data. It uses the well known CSV (Comma Separated Value) format. CSV is recognized by almost every Office Suite or database tool on the market. In case youu want to develop your own report application most programming languages also come with a standard library that knows how to parse CSV format.

Direct Database Connection: so to speak this not a Data Export. It is rather a direct connection to your project database through an ODBC or JDBC driver. If you want to manipulate your project data with a database tool (like MS-Access or an ODBC/JDBC application) this is certainly the best choice.

section.title: Exported Data
section.para: CodeX gives access to the following data (details on exported fields are listed on the CodeX page):

listitem.para: Bug: all bugs submitted to your project.
Bug History: full history of all the changes your project bugs have gone through.
Bug-to-Bug Dependencies: a list of all bug to bug dependencies.
Bug-to-Task Dependencies: a list of all bug to task dependencies.
Task: all tasks created in your project
Task History: full history of all the changes your project tasks have gone through
Task-to-Task Dependencies: a list of all task to task dependencies
Task Assignees: an SQL like form of task assignees. A task may be listed several times if it has several assignees.
Support Request: all support requests submitted to your project
Survey Responses: all responses to all the surveys you have created in your project.

section.title: Text File Export
section.para: Text File Export follow the well known CSV (Comma Separated Values) format, recognized by almost every Office Suite on the market. It can easily be imported in MS-Access, Excel, StarCalc…

section.title: Importing CSV Files in Excel
section.para: Double-clicking on any of the table export link (Bug Export, Task Export,..) on the Project Data Export page generates and downloads a CSV file that you can save on your local disk or directly open in Excel or any other spreadsheet of your choice (StarCalc, QuattroPro,...). No particular setting is required.

section.title: Importing CSV Files in MS-Access
section.para: Before you import external data you must first create a new database. Then go through the following steps:

listitem.para: Select File Menu -> Get External Data -> Import
Choose the appropriate CSV file that you have just generated and then click on the Import... button. A preview of the imported table shows up on the screen
Click on the Advanced... button
Set Text Delimiter to " (double quote)
Set Date Format to YMD
Set Date delimiter to - (dash)
Then enter the name and the type of each field in the lower part of the dialog box. Remember that this information is available on the Project Data Export page.

para.note: Important Remark: you can leave the default field name (Field1,....FieldN) as well as the default Text type in most cases. However long text fields like bug/tasks follow-up comments (details field) and original comment must be declared as type Memo. Failing to do so will cause MS-Access to corrupt the imported data.

section.para: Once you are done with the specification of the Import, save it by clicking on the Save As... button. For future import of the same table simply click on the Specs... button and reload your Import specification.

section.title: Direct Database Access
section.para: To offer maximum flexibility CodeX also provides a direct access to your project data via an ODBC or JDBC database connection. Once installed on your PC the MySQL ODBC (or JDBC) driver allows a transparent access to your project specific database tables.
If you use MS-Access to generate your progress or status report then the 'Direct Database Access' is the easiest way to access all of your project data in no time.

section.title: Generating Your Project Database
section.para: Before you attempt to access your project data with MS-Access or anyother ODBC/JDBC capable application you must first generate your project database. Go to the Project Admin -> Project Data Export and click on the 'Generate Full Project Database' link at the bottom of the page.The 'Generate Full Project Database' link generates a snapshot of your project data. This means you must click on the link again each time you want the project database to be updated with current data.

If everything goes well your project database will be generated in real time and a message will tell you about the result of the generation process and what are the parameters to use to connect to the remote database from your desktop. Write them down and keep them in a safe place.

para.note: Remark: if your project database contains several thousands of records (tasks, bugs,…) it may take the project database generation may take several minutes to complete.

section.title: Installing and Configuring the MySQL ODBC Driver

step.para: First download the MySQL ODBC driver and unzip the zip archive in a temporary directory of your choice.
Run the setup program and go through the installation process.Important Remark: On Windows NT/2000/XP you must have administrator rights to install the driver.
Add your project database to Windows Data Sources. For Windows NT/2000/XP users:

listitem.para: Use your normal user account to logon.
Go to Start menu -> Settings -> Control Panel -> Administrative Tools -> Data Sources (ODBC)
Select the "User DSN" tab and then click on the "Add" button
Select the "MySQL" item from the list and then click on the "Finish" button
A dialog box will pop up asking for the database following connections parameters:
Windows DSN Name: is your choice of a name for this connection. Use "Project X Database" for instance.
MySQL host (IP or Name); codex.xerox.com
MySQL Database Name: the database name is your project shortname as displayed by CodeX after you generated your project database (see above)
User: the user name is 'cxuser'.
Password: No password (leave blank).
Port (if not 3306): use the default port (leave blank).
SQL command on connect: none (leave blank).

section.title: Installing and Configuring the MySQL JDBC Driver
section.para: For those using a Java application based on a JDBC driver, the MySQL JDBC driver and installation instructions are available on the MySQL Java Connectivity page.

section.title: Using Your Project Database From MS-Access
section.para: Before you use MS-Access to connect to your project database make sure that the MySQL OBDC driver has been installed on your PC (see ) and that you have generated your project database (see ). Then go through the following steps:

listitem.para: Launch MS-Access and open a new database.
In the File Menu select Get External Data -> Import.
In the File of Types pull down menu select the ODBC Databases item.
Select the Machine Data Source tab and click on your project database.
Select the tables you are interested or simply click on Select All.

section.para: MS-Access will instantly (according to MS-Access standards :-) import your project data and you can then process your project data exactly as you would do for a native MS-Access database.

section.title: Edit/Release Files

para.emphasis: Location: Project Administration Menu and Page Admin Content

section.para: This service allows project members to post packaged versions (zip or tar gzipped ) of their software on CodeX for public consumption. All posted file releases can be accessed from the Project Summary page.
is entirely dedicated to the description of the File Release Service.

section.title: Post/Edit Jobs
section.para: CodeX offers a minimal job posting system to your project. When you publish a job it instantly appears under the "Project Help Wanted" section on the CodeX Main Menu and is visible to all CodeX users including those who are not registered users. It is an excellent way of calling for help either on a specific topic or to sub-contract a part of your work.

important.title: Important Note on Job Posting
important.para: It is not the intent of the CodeX Job Posting system to replace PeopleNet or any other countrywide job posting system already in place in Xerox. The CodeX Job Posting system is intended to call for expertise or short mission request. One of the possible uses of the CodeX Job Posting system is for Projects to post 3 to 6 months jobs that can be sub-contracted to organizations like XConnect or XISS/XPS. It can also be a request for the opinion of an expert that would take no longer than a couple of days even a couple of hours.

section.title: Source Code Access Logs
section.para:
CodeX is about Software Sharing inside Xerox. Our goal is to make software re-use part of the Xerox culture. To this end, Source code access and file release download is granted to all registered users
Anonymous users are not granted access to the Source code. They must create their own account and identify themselves with CodeX before they can do so. on CodeX. Beside that we also wanted the ability for project leaders to see who downloaded their software. The CodeX Team implemented this feature upon request of several project administrators shortly after the site was launched. The intent for the project leaders is not to construct barriers to source code sharing but rather to know who their community of users are and who is interested in their software.
The Source Code Access Logs provide project members with 2 lists:

listitem.para: The first list is about File Release download. It basically reports who (Real Name, Login name and e-mail), downloaded what file and when (date and time). The time of download is reported in local time relative to the project member time zone.
The second list is about CodeX users who used CVS to checkout or update the sources on their local desktop machine.

figure.title: Source Code Access Logs for a CodeX project

section.title: Tools Admin
section.para: Finally, you'll find here a direct link to the administration function of all your project services in the lower left corner of the Project Admin page. Only project members with Tool Administration permission are allowed to access the CodeX services administration pages.
